entries.skippy_text: Do they see this comet? Yes, certainly they do. Do they know our dropship is under this ice? No way. Or, I don't think so. Unlikely. Very unlikely.
entries.trigger: They see us? They know we're here?

entries.skippy_text: Relay stations are common rendezvous points, Joe, this is not entirely unexpected. Unfortunate, not unusual. They could be, yes, they are, exchanging data, shhhhh, be quiet a minute, will you, I'm listening to them. Darn. Joe, we got a problem. The good news is those ships are simply exchanging data and going to be on their way, they're not aware of us and they're not looking for us. The bad news is they are waiting for another ship to join them, and while they're waiting, they will be engaged in a cross-decking operation. Exchanging supplies, and crews, between ships. They will have crew outside the ships in suits, and dropships flying around between ships, they will not want a ball of ice creating a hazard by flying near them. It is possible they will hit us with a maser, to knock us onto a different course, and so avoid their formation. I'm sorry.
entries.trigger: What the hell are they doing here?

entries.skippy_text: Sure, I can make myself small as a tube of lipstick, and I can become essentially invisible to sensors. Why?
entries.trigger: Damn it! Uh, what can I do? Uh, hey, if you're by yourself, you're small enough they won't see you, right?

entries.skippy_text: Whoa! Wait just a minute, monkeybrain, you're going to toss me out an airlock?
entries.trigger: Because, you can flyby that relay station by yourself, you don't need this dropship.

entries.skippy_text: You will be affected, you ass!
entries.trigger: For real this time, and very gently. I'll give you a little push, you float away and fly right by that relay. That way, if the Kristang do hit this comet, you won't be affected.

entries.skippy_text: Yeah, risk of you shooting yourself in the foot, you idiot. Joe, this is, and I'm adding emphasis here, a gargantuanly stupid idea, even by monkey standards.
entries.trigger: That's a risk. The Army did mention there might be risks involved, when they gave me a rifle. I had to sign a form about it.

entries.skippy_text: No.
entries.trigger: I am open to other ideas, Skippy. Other ideas where you fly by the relay without being detected, get the data we need, and are safely taken back aboard the Dutchman . You got anything like that?

entries.skippy_text: In this case, 'no' means, not yet! Damn, you monkeys are impatient.
entries.trigger: Great, then we-

entries.skippy_text: Define 'fine' for me, in terms of you. If they hit this iceball with a maser-
entries.trigger: Listen, Skippy, in meatsack time, you've had only seconds to think up an alternative idea. In your time, what, you had, what, years? If you haven't thought up something yet, you probably won't, because there is no alternative. You'll be fine floating in space for a while by yourself, I'll be fine here.

entries.skippy_text: I'm a soldier, Skippy, the mission comes first, Ok? There is one of me, and billions of monkeys, damn it, now you've got me saying it, billions of humans on Earth. This mission has almost no margin for error, you told me our only likely chance to track that surveyor ship is to pull data off that relay. I need you to do that for me, and not to worry about me. Can you do that?
entries.trigger: Listen, Skippy, in meatsack time, you've had only seconds to think up an alternative idea. In your time, what, you had, what, years? If you haven't thought up something yet, you probably won't, because there is no alternative. You'll be fine floating in space for a while by yourself, I'll be fine here.

entries.skippy_text: I have to worry about you, Joe, you are a particularly dumb monkey in an unforgiving universe. You clearly can't take care of yourself. You're the monkey who says 'ooh, leopard has pretty spots, I should touch it'.
entries.trigger: Listen, Skippy, in meatsack time, you've had only seconds to think up an alternative idea. In your time, what, you had, what, years? If you haven't thought up something yet, you probably won't, because there is no alternative. You'll be fine floating in space for a while by yourself, I'll be fine here.

entries.skippy_text: I do not like this, Joe, I do not like this one tiny bit.
entries.trigger: Skippy, you get the data from that relay, and I promise you, I will never try to pet a leopard. Deal?

entries.skippy_text: I suppose. Damn, why can't you pick this time to come up with one of your crazy ideas?
entries.trigger: It's not like I'm jumping for joy about it either, Skippy. Do we have a deal?

entries.skippy_text: I see your point. Let's get this over with.
entries.trigger: This isn't crazy enough for you?

entries.skippy_text: Off to your left, give me a good push, or we won't get far enough apart for it to matter. On three, Ok? Three, two, one, now!
entries.trigger: Which way?

entries.skippy_text: Too late now, anyway. Yes, that was a good push, I will come another three thousand kilometers closer to the relay station. Stop talking now, you have to go silent. I can talk to you, but you can't reply. Good luck, Colonel Joe.
entries.trigger: Was that good?

entries.skippy_text: Joe! They're firing a maser at you!
entries.trigger: Then, I waited.
entries.context: That would not be my first choice, in case you were wondering. There were many, many cheeseburgers I wanted to enjoy before I died. Then, I waited.

entries.skippy_text: In case you're wondering why you are still alive, they're using a low-power maser. They are not trying to blast the comet apart, that would create a bigger hazard for them, as then they would have to keep track of many small objects, instead of one medium-size one. The low-power maser is heating up one side of the comet, boiling off ice, and that's making the comet change course. In case you were wondering why I didn't mention this possibility before, I wasn't sure this is what they would do for certain. Didn't want you to get your hopes up. Sometimes, the Kristang like to use comets for target practice, and that would not have been good for you. Nothing to worry about for now.
entries.trigger: All I felt was the comet shaking slightly and moving around. Jiggling, kind of. Gently vibrating.
entries.context: It didn't happen. All I felt was the comet shaking slightly and moving around. Jiggling, kind of. Gently vibrating.

entries.skippy_text: Not to worry, Joe, a chunk of ice broke off, that's all. They've switched aim to boil that chunk of ice to nothing, and, they're done. They're switching back to the comet. Uh, hmm. Now this could become a problem. The comet is rotating so that the maser will hit the hole in about twelve minutes. Voids in comets are not that unusual, however, the hole we made is rather large, for the size of the comet. And when the tarp is exposed, that will certainly look suspicious. Let me think on this.
entries.trigger: For now? Damn, it was driving me crazy that I couldn't talk back to him. Trying to relax, I took in some deep breaths, as the comet vibrated gently around me. Not too relaxed, I had to remind myself not to let go of the dead man's switch by accident. The worst part, if that happened, would not be me
entries.context: For now? Damn, it was driving me crazy that I couldn't talk back to him. Trying to relax, I took in some deep breaths, as the comet vibrated gently around me. Not too relaxed, I had to remind myself n Then the comet lurched to one side.

entries.skippy_text: And while I'm thinking, don't do anything stupid like trying to use the dropship's engines or thrusters.
entries.trigger: For now? Damn, it was driving me crazy that I couldn't talk back to him. Trying to relax, I took in some deep breaths, as the comet vibrated gently around me. Not too relaxed, I had to remind myself not to let go of the dead man's switch by accident. The worst part, if that happened, would not be me
entries.context: For now? Damn, it was driving me crazy that I couldn't talk back to him. Trying to relax, I took in some deep breaths, as the comet vibrated gently around me. Not too relaxed, I had to remind myself n Then the comet lurched to one side.

entries.skippy_text: Got it! Sort of. I think. The good news is, this is going to be cool either way, because I've never done this before. The bad news is, ah, it could be a spectacular failure. Thus, guaranteed cool either way, huh? Coolest, of course, if you survive. That goes without saying, right? Man, I wish you could see this, it is majorly cool. To me. Maybe not to a monkey. Still, totally cool.
entries.trigger: Think faster, Skippy,
entries.context: Then the comet lurched to one side.

entries.skippy_text: It's working, Joe! I think. Hmm. Maybe, uh, yup, yup, it's working. Sort of. Close enough, right? Heh, heh.
entries.trigger: What was driving me crazy was not that I didn't know what crazy thing he was trying, it was not being able to interrupt him rambling on and on. The comet's vibration changed, I don't what was going on or how to describe it, it simply felt different. Maybe like there were two sources of vibration.
entries.context: What was driving me crazy was not that I didn't know what crazy thing he was trying, it was not being able to interrupt him rambling on and on. The comet's vibration changed, I don't what was going on

entries.skippy_text: Where was I, oh, yeah, explaining what I'm doing. Ha! Explaining high-order multidimensional physics to a monkey, what am I thinking? I'll break it down for you Barney style. Joke intended, thought that was pretty clever of me. Man, I never get tired of that one. Only you, Joe, would combat an alien invasion in an ice cream truck. Not even a nice ice cream truck. A crappy ice cream truck. So, here goes, this will blow your tiny monkey mind. I'm warping spacetime, in a tiny, tiny area, to make the comet spin just a bit differently than it was. Differently enough that the maser beam will miss the hole we made. Cool, huh? Hell, you know what, I've never warped spacetime in such a tiny local area, the math is completely different, it's interesting. In fact, I don't think it's ever been done before. I'm the first! Cool, huh-
entries.trigger: I could have prayed for death right then, if that would get him to shut the hell up.
entries.context: At the sound of 'heh heh', the hairs on the back of my neck stood up. What the hell was he doing? I could have prayed for death right then, if that would get him to shut the hell up.

entries.skippy_text: -you still listening, Joe? I think you're good, I think you'll be safe. That maser should cut off in a couple minutes, the Kristang are about satisfied they've pushed it safely out of the way.
entries.trigger: He rambled on and on like that a while, I'm not sure how long, I stopped listening. Maybe he talked the whole twelve minutes, he must have, he was talking when the twelve minutes passed. About what, I don't remember. It didn't matter, it was good simply to hear his voice, to hear someone talking to
entries.context: I could have prayed for death right then, if that would get him to shut the hell up. He rambled on and on like that a while, I'm not sure how long, I stopped listening. Maybe he talked the whole twelve minutes, he must have, he was talking when the twelve minutes passed. About what, I

entries.skippy_text: You're good, Joe! Maser is off, the Kristang commander is happy the comet will miss their formation. They are proceeding with the cross-decking operation. Wow, hmmm, they boiled off more of the comet than I expected, more than was strictly necessary, it's a good thing we didn't pick a smaller comet, or part of the dropship may be exposed by now. You can turn off the stealth field to save power, Joe. Hey, good thing they didn't need target practice to tune their masers, huh? That would not have been good. Anywho, I'm going to stop talking in about eighteen minutes, I'm approaching the relay station and I will need to concentrate, or all this will be for nothing. In a couple hours, we will have drifted far enough apart that I won't be able to talk to you. Until I have to go, here is a medley of show tunes to keep you company. Oklahoma, where the wind comes sweeping down the plain-
entries.trigger: He rambled on and on like that a while, I'm not sure how long, I stopped listening. Maybe he talked the whole twelve minutes, he must have, he was talking when the twelve minutes passed. About what, I don't remember. It didn't matter, it was good simply to hear his voice, to hear someone talking to
entries.context: I could have prayed for death right then, if that would get him to shut the hell up. He rambled on and on like that a while, I'm not sure how long, I stopped listening. Maybe he talked the whole twelve minutes, he must have, he was talking when the twelve minutes passed. About what, I

entries.skippy_text: Hey, Joe! Good to have you back! After the ship recovered me, it had to jump away, it would have taken too long to fly through normal space to pick you up, the ship would have been exposed for too long. We waited until you got far away from the relay, before we risked coming back. Hold tight, they're cutting a hole for you, should only be a minute before you can come out.
entries.trigger: And, wouldn't you know it, just as I was drifting off to sleep, the console alerted me to another gamma ray burst, and the Dutchman
entries.context: And, wouldn't you know it, just as I was drifting off to sleep, the console alerted me to another gamma ray burst, and the Dutchman pinged me with a brief signal. 'Taking you aboard shortly, ETA four minutes'.

entries.skippy_text: We're in luck, Joe! Although, now that I think about it, that expression can be rather ambiguous, isn't it? Luck can be good or bad. No matter, in this case, our luck is good. Success, yes! Sort of. Come aboard, and I'll give you a full briefing. You, uh, better shower first, huh?
entries.trigger: Thanks, Skippy, it's great to hear your voice again. Were you successful? With the relay, I mean.
entries.context: And, wouldn't you know it, just as I was drifting off to sleep, the console alerted me to another gamma ray burst, and the Dutchman pinged me with a brief signal. 'Taking you aboard shortly, ETA four minutes'.

entries.skippy_text: Here's what I found, Joe, not sure if in the end it is good news or bad news-
entries.trigger: Thanks, Skippy, it's great to hear your voice again. Were you successful? With the relay, I mean.
entries.context: ---CHAPTER_BREAK---

entries.skippy_text: My expectation, that the Fire Dragon clan would have information about the surveyor ship's mission, was partly correct.
entries.trigger: No, go ahead.

entries.skippy_text: No, unfortunately, no, the Fire Dragons have no information about the surveyor ship, or about the single destroyer that is serving as escort.
entries.trigger: Great! You know where the surveyor ship is, and where it's going?

entries.skippy_text: I did say that. Can you hear me, Joe?
entries.trigger: Then what could be the good news? You said two of the Fire Dragons were going on the mission to Earth, and that the surveyor ship had to pick them up somewhere.

entries.skippy_text: Good. Yes, two Fire Dragon clan leaders are going on the mission to Earth, they paid extra for the privilege, because they do not trust the Thuranin. For very good reasons, based on a long history, the Kristang do not trust the Thuranin. The Thuranin don't trust the Kristang, also for very good reasons. The Thuranin enjoy insulting and humiliating the Kristang every chance they get, which is why these two Fire Dragon leaders were not instructed to rendezvous with the surveyor ship. They will instead be picked up by a pair of tanker support ships. To travel aboard such low-status ships is a deliberate, very grave insult, and the Kristang know it is an insult. They also can't do anything about it.
entries.trigger: Yeah, I can hear you just fine,

entries.skippy_text: ’Where’ is a question I do know the answer to, and I've programmed a course into the navigation computer. When is the problem, Joe. The Kristang are arriving at those tankers three days from now, we can't get there so quickly.
entries.trigger: I feel terrible for them, we should send a harsh note to the Thuranin. Where are they going to meet these tanker ships? And when?

entries.skippy_text: No, I do not. That is not the type of information the Thuranin saw fit to provide to the Fire Dragon clan.
entries.trigger: Crap. You know where those tankers are going, though, right?

entries.skippy_text: I suppose so, you haven't heard-
entries.trigger: Well, hell, Skippy, This was all a waste of time, then? We're too late? Wait. There's always a chance something goes wrong, that the Kristang could be late to the rendezvous?

entries.skippy_text: I already did, Joe, the course I programmed does include one shortcut by manipulating a wormhole. You didn't-
entries.trigger: Aye, aye,

entries.skippy_text: Joe! If you will please shut the hell up for a minute, you haven't heard the whole story.
entries.trigger: Aye, aye,

entries.skippy_text: I tried to, you big dope, only you kept flapping your lips 'blah blah blah'. Damn, you flap your lips so hard sometimes, I think you are going to take off like a bird.
entries.trigger: Skippy, that's fantastic! Why didn't you say that first?

entries.skippy_text: It's a planet, Joe, not a gas station. The operation to siphon the proper gases-
entries.trigger: Sorry. Ok, so, we know where these tankers will be, and we know they will be meeting the surveyor ship after they finish pumping their tanks full at this gas station.

entries.skippy_text: It's complicated, that's what I was going to say. We still have the problem that we don't know where the tankers are going, after they fuel up. And we have no way to follow them, without them knowing they are being followed.
entries.trigger: You know what I mean, Skippy.

entries.skippy_text: Hey! I wasn't hostile. Perhaps I wasn't as polite as-
entries.trigger: Sir, we may be missing something, I read the after action report from your first mission. The Kristang ships that were attached to the Dutchman , you decided to jump them into a gas giant planet, because you were concerned they would eject drones that contain those ships' flight logs. A drone's logs would have told the Kristang, or Thuranin, that a Kristang frigate and a Thuranin star carrier had
entries.context: “You having an idea, that’s what scares me.” The Flying Dutchman was jumping like clockwork, on our way to the star system where the two Thuranin support ships should even then be filling their tanks with fuel. According to Skippy, we should arr

entries.skippy_text: Oh. Understood. Hostile in this case means taking over their ships and killing all of them. I guess that could be considered hostile, In certain cultures.
entries.trigger: Skippy, that's not what he meant,
entries.context: The Flying Dutchman was jumping like clockwork, on our way to the star system where the two Thuranin support ships should even then be filling their tanks with fuel. According to Skippy, we should arr

entries.skippy_text: It's possible,
entries.trigger: Right. Well, then, when we attack these ships, assuming by that time we have some plan to destroy them, during the attack, those ships will eject stealth drones. Those drones may tell the Thuranin that their ships were attacked by one ship, and they might even be able to determine that one ship is a former Thuranin ship.

entries.skippy_text: Yeah, Joe, That's a good point. That is a very good point. You got an answer for that, smart guy?
entries.trigger: That's the problem, sir, we have to both destroy those ships, and do it in a way that the Thuranin think it was an ordinary Jeraptha raid. Those drones will blow our cover story.

entries.skippy_text: Oh, I am? And how am I going to do that? Maybe you weren't paying attention, so I'll summarize the problem for you, Starships carry drones which contain the ship's flight recorder data. When a ship is destroyed, or seriously damaged, one or many of those drones are ejected. They are tiny, and they are stealthed. Our sensor field will not be able to detect all the drones, and that, Joey my boy, is the problem; the Thuranin will eventually send a ship to find out what happened to their precious surveyor and its escorts. I am hoping, of course, to fool their sensors into thinking our ship is a Jeraptha cruiser, but that is not guaranteed to work.
entries.trigger: Sure, Skippy, you're going to take care of that problem for us.

entries.skippy_text: Hmm. Since I left my magic unicorn back on Paradise or somewhere, how am I supposed to find an unknown number of stealthed drones, smart guy?
entries.trigger: Not a problem, Skippy. You can handle that easily.

entries.skippy_text: Perhaps I need to explain the concept of 'stealth' to you again, Joe.
entries.trigger: Simple, Skippy. By asking them to tell us where they are.

entries.skippy_text: Sir, I might know what you're thinking.
entries.trigger: No, I understa-

entries.skippy_text: Oh, this is going to be good, Go ahead, Sergeant Adams, enlighten me, please.
entries.trigger: No, I understa-

entries.skippy_text: Skippster?
entries.trigger: Skippster-

entries.skippy_text: When I load a virus into the Thuranin computer, to make the ship drop off a drone before it jumps, with that drone containing their rendezvous coordinates, I am also supposed to download the drone retrieval codes, right?
entries.trigger: You get it now, Skippy?

entries.skippy_text: That, yes, I can do that. Damn it, you monkeys think you're so smart. Sergeant Adams, I thought I hated Colonel Joe the worst, but you're moving up the list.
entries.trigger: You can do that, Skippy?

entries.skippy_text: After I tell the drones to ping us their location, we use them for target practice?
entries.trigger: I'm honored,

entries.skippy_text: Huh. All right, apparently I'm still missing something here,
entries.trigger: No, no, I don't want to destroy them,

entries.skippy_text: Two light cruisers,
entries.trigger: We're not going to destroy them, those drone aren’t going to blow our cover story. They’re going to sell our cover story for us. After you locate and access them, you are going to alter their flight logs, so all the drones contain data showing their ships were attacked by a Jeraptha task force, whatever number and types of ships the Jeraptha would most likely assign to such a mission-

entries.skippy_text: Damn, That actually is a fairly good plan. From a monkey, amazing. That plan is ingeniously devious, and I'm saying that as a compliment. Joe, I'm telling you, once you're done playing soldier, you have a bright career ahead of you as a criminal mastermind. Or, you, know, politics.
entries.trigger: Then you'll tell those drones to go silent again, until a real Thuranin ship comes looking for them. If that ever happens. Whatever ship finds the drones will provide convincing data about that surveyor ship being destroyed by the Jeraptha, and they will have no reason to suspect humans were involved. Those drones will sell the story for us.

entries.skippy_text: How about crime?
entries.trigger: Skippy, I would never do anything as sleazy as politics.

entries.skippy_text: I have to admit, this barrel of monkeys has come up with some decent ideas.
entries.trigger: Crime we can talk about later, I have plenty of playing soldier to do first.

entries.skippy_text: Uh huh, yup, excellent observation skills you have there, Joe. I took over the Dutchman with my incredible awesomeness. However, since you apparently weren't paying attention at the time, the Thuranin brought the Flower into a docking pad, before I was able to seize control of their crude computer and put those idiot cyborgs into sleep mode. To do that, I had to be close, Joe, by close I mean within about ten thousand kilometers. We got that close because the Flying Dutchman is a star carrier, that expected to be taking a Kristang frigate aboard. None of the Thuranin ships in the surveyor task force will let an unknown ship come that close to them.
entries.trigger: What? You took over this ship like, that. In the blink of an eye! How did you do that?

entries.skippy_text: But you were having so much fun, Joe, I didn't want to spoil it for you.
entries.trigger: Well, hell, Skippy, you could have told us that earlier, before we wasted all this time dreaming up impossible plans.

entries.skippy_text: Pathetic would be more accurate,
entries.trigger: We're not here for fun, Skippy, We may be stupid monkeys to you, but the monkey brains on this ship, and you are all we've got to come up with a plan to stop that surveyor ship from destroying our home. You think this is funny-

entries.skippy_text: You really-
entries.trigger: Again with you not paying attention, Joe. You seem distracted. Are you hungry, or is this just you being perpetually horny so you can't think straight? I didn't say it was not possible, I said it was not easy. There is a huge difference between those.

entries.skippy_text: Let me explain it to you, We know those two support ships will be tanking up from the second planet in that system, a gas giant. We jump in behind the fourth planet, another gas giant, we jump in on the far side so the planet will mask the gamma rays from our entry. Then someone takes me on a stealth flyby close to one of those support ships, and I can hack in.
entries.trigger: Again with you not paying attention, Joe. You seem distracted. Are you hungry, or is this just you being perpetually horny so you can't think straight? I didn't say it was not possible, I said it was not easy. There is a huge difference between those.

entries.skippy_text: Nope, it's not going to be that easy, Joe. To hack in while I'm flying by, I will need to be within about four thousand kilometers at the closest approach. A dropship, even stealthed, would be detected at that range. And the Thuranin wouldn't let a comet get within four thousand kilometers of them, they'd either move it away or blast it to pieces.
entries.trigger: Oh, like flying by that relay station. That's a great idea, Skippy. We do the flyby in a dropship again?

entries.skippy_text: Well, heh, heh, you're not going to like this idea.
entries.trigger: No dropship? Then how are we supposed to fly from one planet to another?

entries.skippy_text: There's the first ship, Right on time, it hasn't altered its orbit at all. Picking up ship to ship transmissions, there are still only those two support ships in system.
entries.trigger: The sensors built into my suit were not sensitive enough to detect the ships yet, I had to take Desai's word for it. For the next four and a half hours, I zoomed through empty space, the planet ahead of me growing larger in my vision. Really, I was racing through space, only there was no sensation o
entries.context: The sensors built into my suit were not sensitive enough to detect the ships yet, I had to take Desai's word for it. For the next four and a half hours, I zoomed through empty space, the planet ahead  If all went well.

entries.skippy_text: Uh, oh, we've got a problem. A big, big problem.
entries.trigger: The sensors built into my suit were not sensitive enough to detect the ships yet, I had to take Desai's word for it. For the next four and a half hours, I zoomed through empty space, the planet ahead of me growing larger in my vision. Really, I was racing through space, only there was no sensation o
entries.context: If all went well. A symbol for the first ship popped up on the inside of my helmet faceplate, it was hugging the crescent of the planet, climbing away slowly. We waited, and a symbol for the second ship popped up, it w

entries.skippy_text: No, those crappy ships couldn't see us yet even if we were lighting off fireworks out here. That second ship has been slower to take on fuel because of a fault with its drogue, the unit at the bottom of the fuel line it has lowered into the atmosphere. The fault has gotten worse, the Thuranin have decided to retract the fuel line now, even though the ship's tanks are only 82% full.
entries.trigger: What is it? They detected us?
entries.context: A symbol for the first ship popped up on the inside of my helmet faceplate, it was hugging the crescent of the planet, climbing away slowly. We waited, and a symbol for the second ship popped up, it w

entries.skippy_text: So, as soon as the drogue is clear of the atmosphere, that ship will be changing course to join the other ship, climbing out of orbit to jump distance. From its transmissions, I can predict the ship's course, and it is a very big problem. The jetpack does not have enough fuel to alter our course sufficiently that we can intercept that ship, not within four thousand kilometers. We'll be too far away for me to hack into their systems. I'm sorry, Joe, we're going to miss this chance.
entries.trigger: Yeah, so?

entries.skippy_text: Yes, I am sure. The degree of uncertainty is not great enough to make us intercepting that ship be a realistic possibility. It is simple orbital mechanics, Joe, the jetpack does not contain enough fuel.
entries.trigger: This is our only chance. You sure where that ship is going?

entries.skippy_text: Um, yeah. I'm surprised you know-
entries.trigger: Force equals mass times acceleration?

entries.skippy_text: Correct. Between me, you, the stealth field generator, and the suit, the jetpack can't manage to provide the delta vee, the change in velocity, for us to alter course sufficiently to come close to that ship.
entries.trigger: Our problem right now isn't the acceleration part, it's the mass, right?

entries.skippy_text: Mostly the suit, it has more than twice your mass, Joe.
entries.trigger: The problem isn't you, either, it's me and this suit.

entries.skippy_text: Joe, what are you doing? We need that jetpack, you dumb monkey.
entries.trigger: Yeah, I can't take the suit off, so.

entries.skippy_text: A course? Where? Back to the dropship?
entries.trigger: No, Skippy, you need the jetpack. There, done. Tell me how to program a course into this thing,

entries.skippy_text: May I point out the glaringly obvious flaw in your plan, you brainless monkey?
entries.trigger: No, Skippy, a course to take you within four thousand kilometers of that tanker ship. You said it, we're going to miss this chance if the jetpack has to move my mass. This is our only chance, Skippy, our only chance to follow that ship to the surveyor and destroy it. Our only chance to stop the Thuranin from reaching my home planet and killing everyone. You are not going to miss that chance. You'r

entries.skippy_text: Shit. Joe, this is the second time you've offered to sacrifice yourself for a noble cause-
entries.trigger: The fact that, without the jetpack, I'm going to hit the atmosphere and burn up? Yeah, I know that, Skippy. I don't need to be reminded of that, thank you very much.

entries.skippy_text: No cause could be more noble indeed.
entries.trigger: The first time, I offered to sacrifice myself for you, you little shithead.

entries.skippy_text: No, astonishing as it may seem, your logic is correct on this one. Damn, why does the monkey pick now to start using logic?
entries.trigger: I offered to sacrifice myself for you, because you're more valuable to the mission than I am. The Dutchman can go on without me, Chang will make a fine commander. That surveyor ship can be stopped without me, but it can't be stopped without you. Unless I'm missing something here.

entries.skippy_text: It will take the tankers longer than you think to reach a safe jump distance; this planet has a deep gravity well and they are heavily loaded with fuel. You are correct, however, that this is the only opportunity I see for being able to track these ships, and locate the surveyor.
entries.trigger: I love you too, Skippy. You see an alternative? If we use the jetpack to rendezvous with the dropship, by the time we get there, those two tankers will have jumped away already, and we'll never find them. We will lose our one chance to intercept that surveyor ship before it reaches Earth.

entries.skippy_text: Given the laws of physics, which I can't screw with because those tankers would detect us, the answer is, unfortunately, no. Joe, I'm sorry.
entries.trigger: Right, Is there any way to get you to within four thousand kilometers of that ship, and also make sure I don't hit the atmosphere? Can we split the difference, use the jetpack to move both of us just enough so I miss the planet, then you fly off to intercept the tanker?

entries.skippy_text: I know that. 'Sorry' is something you monkeys say as a social courtesy, whether you mean it or not. That custom seems particularly stupid now.
entries.trigger: You have nothing to be sorry about.

entries.skippy_text: I don't like this, Joe.
entries.trigger: I appreciate the effort, Skippy. All right, before I change my mind, can you program the jetpack to fly you near that tanker, and I'll engage it with this controller on my wrist?

entries.skippy_text: Jetpack autonomous navigation system has been programmed. Ready. Are you sure about this, Joe? It seems like such a waste.
entries.trigger: I'm not jumping for joy about it either, Skippy.

entries.skippy_text: Legitimately, no, no, I do not have any other idea. Joe, there is a big difference, or there should be, between taking a risk of dying, and taking an action that will result in certain death. Suicide does not seem like something a soldier should do.
entries.trigger: Skippy, I'm a soldier. I knew the risks coming out here, I am not going to do nothing, and let that surveyor ship reach Earth. If you have a better idea, I am all ears.

entries.skippy_text: You'll need to explain that one.
entries.trigger: Skippy, let's get real here, Ok? Yeah, in a way, this is suicide, but really, it is only an issue of timing.

entries.skippy_text: Zero. Well, close enough to zero that your chances of success are statistically insignificant. If you like, I can recite the actual odds to a hundred decimal points, however, I expect you are satisfied with 'meh' level math on this one.
entries.trigger: This whole mission is suicide, I explained that to everyone before we left Earth. Be straight with me, what are the odds we humans can fly the Dutchman back to Earth by ourselves, after you leave us for Collective heaven, or whatever the hell it is you're looking for?

entries.skippy_text: Captain Desai has become a skilled starship pilot, for, you know, a monkey, and she has trained other pilots well enough for basic maneuvers. My calculation of your odds are no reflection on your merry band of pirates, they are all dedicated, and, considering your species' miserably low level of development, reasonably intelligent, no offense.
entries.trigger: You got that right.

entries.skippy_text: Ha, ha! No way, dude, The memory and processing power on the Dutchman are much too small to contain a stable submind. It might work fine for a week, maybe two, then it would start going funky on you, and without me to adjust it, the submind would go senile and destroy the ship, So, no to that one. Before you ask, I could reload the original Thuranin AI into the computer, modified to work with you instead of wiping you out as soon as it became aware of your presence. That would not help, the Thuranin's cyborg nature is integrated into their AIs to such an extent that the AI cannot completely control the ship without them. That is both because the Thuranin wish their minds to be as close as possible to an AI, and because the Thuranin don't want an AI to be able to run the ship without them, for security reasons. Especially because the Thuranin are quite rightly concerned about the Maxohlx hacking into their systems. Many crucial control and maintenance functions require cyborg participation, particularly in controlling the robots. Humans can't fill the role of the Thuranin, and the system's processing substrate lacks the capacity for me to replicate the cyborg function inside it.
entries.trigger: Inside my helmet, I had to smile and roll my eyes. In one sentence, he insults us, and says he intended no offense. Sometimes I wondered about his intelligence.
entries.context: Inside my helmet, I had to smile and roll my eyes. In one sentence, he insults us, and says he intended no offense. Sometimes I wondered about his intelligence.

entries.skippy_text: Unfortunately, I am forced to agree with your point. I still do not like it. Joe, I need to understand something. You came out here, knowing there is almost no possibility that you will ever return to Earth. Why? Why did you come with me?
entries.trigger: Uh huh. Like I said before, this whole fool's errand is a suicide mission, and me falling into this planet is only shortening the trip somewhat for me.

entries.skippy_text: We did it, Joe! Whenever that tanker jumps, it's going to leave behind drones like a trail of breadcrumbs. And, major bonus, I was able to hack into their navigation system, and download data. We now know where and when the tankers will rendezvous with the surveyor ship! This mission is totally successful.
entries.trigger: And, darn it, the view was eerily beautiful. The planet below me was mostly orange in color, when I left the dropship, from that far away it had been an orange blob the size of a basketball. Now I was close enough to see details, and it looked like a creamsicle; swirls of orange and white, with less
entries.context: Man, that was a long forty minutes. On the display inside the helmet faceplate, I was able to track the two tanker ships, they were big, they were close and they weren't using stealth. In fact, their  And, darn it, the view was eerily beautiful. entries.skippy_text: Is there anything I can do, Joe?
entries.context: “So far? Is this like the old joke about the guy who falls off a building, and when he is halfway to the sidewalk below, he thinks to himself ‘Ok so far’?” “Something like that, yeah, Skippy.”

entries.skippy_text: Joe, I have been alive for a very, very long time, millions of years, I think. It just occurred to me that, no matter how much longer I exist, in all the infinite universes of probability, I will never talk to you again. That makes me very sad.
entries.trigger: My helmet speakers played some new age type soothing instrumental thing, something I hadn't heard before. It was nice, and appropriate.
entries.context: My helmet speakers played some new age type soothing instrumental thing, something I hadn't heard before. It was nice, and appropriate.

entries.skippy_text: Joe, what do you want to do with your stuff?
entries.trigger: My helmet speakers played some new age type soothing instrumental thing, something I hadn't heard before. It was nice, and appropriate.
entries.context: My helmet speakers played some new age type soothing instrumental thing, something I hadn't heard before. It was nice, and appropriate.

entries.skippy_text: Without the visor, the faceplate will deteriorate quickly. It is made of a tough material so it won't melt, but it will fog, and you will be blinded anyway.

Although I want to tell you yes, the answer is no. Kristang armor is rugged, it will last longer than you expect. Or, in this case, I'm very sad to say, longer than you will want. The suit will hold together long enough for you to get sufficiently deep in the atmosphere, that the force of deceleration will crush you inside the suit. Other than your bones, your soft tissue will become a liquefied, hmm, guess you don’t need to hear about that. The good news is you should lose consciousness around twelve gees.
entries.trigger: All right, fine. It's going to be quick, right? When I hit the atmosphere, this suit won't last long.

entries.skippy_text: No, no. The outer protective layers of the suit will flake off, in a process called ablation. As the material heats up, it will ablate away, exposing fresh layers below, this protects the integrity of the suit, and the wearer, as long as possible. In combat, ablation technology defends the wearer against directed-energy weapons such as masers and particle beams. And-
entries.trigger: Wow, these suits are super tough. This material can take all that heat?

entries.skippy_text: Give me a minute, I'm working on an idea here, Lots of numbers to crunch, need to run a couple billion simulations though the model I've built.
entries.trigger: And? Skippy? And?

entries.skippy_text: Yesssss! Got it. Joe, while I don't want to get your hopes up too much, there is a possibility that I can do something to help.
entries.trigger: Okey dokey. I'll be right here, got plenty of time and nothing to do.

entries.skippy_text: Well, heh, heh, first thing is, you are very much not going to like this-
entries.trigger: I'm all ears, here, Skippy.

entries.skippy_text: Uh, huh, 'go' it is, got it. Captain Desai, fire on my mark. Three, two, one, mark!
entries.trigger: No! I said 'no'.
entries.context: When Skippy told me his plan, my first thought was that he was offering to kill me in one quick zap, so I wouldn't suffer from being crushed inside my suit. But no, that would have been too easy. Inst

entries.skippy_text: Uh huh, I'm sure. Math don't lie, bro. Tell you what, though, how about you don't move a muscle, stay perfectly still. And try not to breathe too hard, Ok?
entries.trigger: You sure I'm good here, Skippy?
entries.context: It didn't happen. Skippy's plan worked. Surprised the hell out of me, that's for sure. Probably surprised him, too. He had me spin around slowly, so the maser hit different parts of the suit, he had t My second cooking session lasted twenty two minutes, and was less frightening because Skippy didn't have to rush the process, he could let my suit cool and adjust between maser blasts.  The outer lay

entries.skippy_text: Well, heh, heh, the maser really cooked your suit, and patches of it are thin as tissue paper right now. I wouldn't worry about it.
entries.trigger: Why?
entries.context: My second cooking session lasted twenty two minutes, and was less frightening because Skippy didn't have to rush the process, he could let my suit cool and adjust between maser blasts.  The outer laye

entries.skippy_text: Hmm. I see your point. Still, there is no point to you worrying, you can't do anything about it. When the dropship gets there, Captain Desai will open the airlock door and fly the dropship to take you aboard, without you having to move in any way. Once the airlock is closed and repressurized, you can move about all you wish.
entries.trigger: Of course you don't need to worry about it!

entries.skippy_text: Well, certainly not more than one hour, Joe.
entries.trigger: How long will that be?

entries.skippy_text: Because we can't risk hitting you with the maser again, and if those two tankers haven't jumped away within an hour, you're going to fall into the atmosphere, and this time there will be nothing I can do about it.
entries.trigger: Why's that?

entries.skippy_text: Wow, you can hear that, Joe? Your hearing is impressive. That frequency is almost up in the dog hearing range.
entries.trigger: Skippy, am I hearing things again? There's a whistling noise, right at the edge of my hearing.

entries.skippy_text: No can do, sorry. I can't turn it off, because it's a tiny air leak. Well, not so tiny as it was a few minutes ago.
entries.trigger: You know about it? What is it? Can you turn it off? It is very distracting.

entries.skippy_text: There was no reason to worry you about it. Not yet, anyway.
entries.trigger: What? Crap, you knew about this? Why didn't you tell me?

entries.skippy_text: Worrying is not going to solve the problem, Joe.
entries.trigger: Skippy, my air supply is leaking out into space. I have a very good reason to be worried.

entries.skippy_text: I am working on it. The suit has been instructed to move nanoparticles to plug the leak. So far, it isn't working, the suit's supply of nanoparticles has been severely depleted, and the remaining supply is already being used to prevent the suit from springing other leaks. Probably shouldn't have told you about that.
entries.trigger: What will solve the problem?

entries.skippy_text: Ah, not so much, unfortunately. The suit mostly, and efficiently, recycles oxygen. There is a small reserve oxygen bottle. That bottle is inadequate, considering the leak.
entries.trigger: Understood. I have plenty of oxygen, right? Enough to keep me breathing, even with this, as you say, tiny leak?

entries.skippy_text: The leak is near your waist, on the left side. Do not move! Moving will only make the leak worse, and cause other leaks.
entries.trigger: Where is the leak? Can I put my hand over it, or something like that? I can't do nothing, Skippy.

entries.skippy_text: Try to breathe less?
entries.trigger: Great. Wonderful. What can I do?

entries.skippy_text: That wasn't a joke.
entries.trigger: Very funny.

entries.skippy_text: Perhaps I should work on my humor, so you know when I'm joking.
entries.trigger: Shit.

entries.skippy_text: Sorry,
entries.trigger: Ya think?

entries.skippy_text: An idea? You? This I have to hear.
entries.trigger: Huh, Skippy, I may have an idea.

entries.skippy_text: Ah, not exactly, the water would freeze and boil at the same time, because of the combination of cold and zero pressure. Besides, Joe, you drank all the water, you dumb monkey, there's none left.
entries.trigger: Would water plug the leak? It would freeze, right, make a plug of ice to cover the hole.

entries.skippy_text: Oh.
entries.trigger: There's no pure water left.

entries.skippy_text: Unfortunately, yuck, yes. I can puncture the bag with nanoparticles.
entries.trigger: You know what I'm thinking?

entries.skippy_text: It's working, Joe! It's boiling off slowly, which is not a problem, there's plenty more. Good idea, Joe!
entries.trigger: Do that. Ugh.

entries.skippy_text: Yeah, like that's gonna happen, No way can I pass up a golden opportunity to leak this info,
entries.trigger: Yes! Outstanding. Uh, hey, Skippy, this little incident, this can stay just between us, right? No need to tell anybody about it.

entries.skippy_text: Sir? Mr. Skippy said your suit is in bad condition.
entries.trigger: Desai, take Skippy aboard first,
entries.context: When they finally did jump away thirty four minutes later, I almost shouted for joy. Mercifully, Desai put the pedal to the metal on the dropship's engines to rescue me. Instead, I ordered Skippy to s Dutchman to jump into orbit, and for Desai to come pick us up. The dropship was suddenly close to us, Desai making no effort at stealth, she was burning the engines at full power.

entries.skippy_text: No, it smells like-
entries.trigger: The suit got cooked a bit by the maser,

entries.skippy_text: As a problem solver,
entries.trigger: The suit got cooked a bit by the maser,

entries.skippy_text: When a problem needs to be solved, Joe doesn't waste time trying to piss up a rope .
entries.trigger: Skippy-

entries.skippy_text: Joe knows you can't put out a forest fire by peeing on it, but you can-
entries.trigger: All right, Skippy.

entries.skippy_text: Yeah, uh huh, that's our story and we're sticking to it.
entries.trigger: Enough! The maser busted the, you know, bag,

entries.skippy_text: No problem, Joe. If you're not here, who will amuse me with monkey-brained ideas?
entries.trigger: Skippy, that didn't go exactly as planned, but we did accomplish the mission. Your maser idea was a stroke of genius, thank you for that.
entries.context: I had an idea, the unformed kernel of an idea, I needed to think more on it before mentioning it to anyone, especially Skippy. The last thing I wanted was to give that arrogant little beer can even mo And I needed to get out of my sweat and other fluid soaked clothes, and I needed a shower. Seriously.

entries.skippy_text: Yeah, speaking of monkey-brained ideas, you know where each of those four ships are going to jump into, right, pretty precisely? And you know when, also?
entries.trigger: Skippy, that didn't go exactly as planned, but we did accomplish the mission. Your maser idea was a stroke of genius, thank you for that.
entries.context: I had an idea, the unformed kernel of an idea, I needed to think more on it before mentioning it to anyone, especially Skippy. The last thing I wanted was to give that arrogant little beer can even mo And I needed to get out of my sweat and other fluid soaked clothes, and I needed a shower. Seriously.

entries.skippy_text: Not a problem. I got that covered.
entries.trigger: Yup. I told you that. You said 'mission accomplished', I do not think that is entirely accurate. We only accomplished the first, less important part of the mission. We know where those ships will be meeting, and when. We still have to attack those ships, and we do not have a realistic plan, hell, any plan, for doing that.

entries.skippy_text: You? Thinking? I find that hard to believe, but, sure, what the hell, surprise me.
entries.trigger: Skippy, while I was space diving by myself, I did some thinking.

entries.skippy_text: Hmm, a monkey plan. Does this involve, let me guess, magic bananas?
entries.trigger: I came up with a plan for us to destroy all four of those ships. Or at least three of them, one of the tankers may get away. That shouldn't be a problem. Letting one tanker get away, if it thinks we're a Jeraptha cruiser, might actually be useful to us.

entries.skippy_text: Damn, Joe, what fun is that?
entries.trigger: Nope. No bananas at all.

entries.skippy_text: Can I assume you do not plan to simply ask the Thuranin to surrender? Because no way would the Thuranin be intimidated by this bucket, we would need a much meaner looking ship. This is why gangsters never drive a minivan, Joe. I mean, come on, how intimidated would you be by a guy driving a minivan with one of those stupid 'Baby on board' signs, and sticky Cheerios all over the back seat?
entries.trigger: Easy, Skippy, we will survive, and be successful, because we're not going to risk the Dutchman in combat.

entries.skippy_text: About that part of your plan, yeah, sure, you're correct. Ships are at their most vulnerable coming out of a jump; they don't have shields up and their sensor fields are scrambled by quantum fluctuations of the wormhole, they're almost blind. So, yes, if you could predict exactly where a ship will emerge from a jump, you can hit it precisely. Even a single missile would destroy, or severely cripple a warship. Now, with those obvious facts established, may I point out the annoying little detail of the fatal flaw in your genius plan?
entries.trigger: Nope, we are not asking the Thuranin to surrender. I plan to hit those ships with missiles, right as they come out of jump at the rendezvous. We will park missiles around the enemy jump target points, with the missiles programmed to hit a ship as it emerges from the wormhole. We'll hit the destroyer first, you told me ships have to drop their stealth and defensive shields to go through a jump worm

entries.skippy_text: That's affirmative. We're supposed to target the missiles toward the precise point where the Thuranin ships will emerge from their jump, huh? The problem with that plan is we do not know exactly where the Thuranin will jump in. The rendezvous coordinates for each ship are only accurate to within a radius of eight thousand kilometers, because that is the limit of accuracy of Thuranin jump navigation technology. Even if we used all of our missiles to saturate the spherical area where a single ship is likely to jump in, it will take any missile too long to detect the ship and close for impact, the target area is too large. Assuming the Thuranin are accurate to within eight thousand kilometers of the target, that is an enormous volume of space to cover. The formula for the volume of a sphere is the radius cubed, times, oh, wait, why am I trying to explain even simple math to you? Joe, a radius of eight thousand kilometers leaves a sphere of over two trillion cubic kilometers to search. While a missile is closing from that distance, the ship would detect the threat and jump away, or raise shields. So, your plan won't work, dumbass.
entries.trigger: You're going to anyway, right?

entries.skippy_text: Oh, sure, if you're asking for miracles. Why don't you ask for fairy elves to fly in on a unicorn and take care of the problem for us? That would be more realistic. Thanks a bunch for the vote of confidence in my predictive abilities, but even my awesomely ginormous brain power can't tell you where a ship is going to jump in, with that level of accuracy. There are too many variables in a particular ship's jump drive at that exact moment. The charge energy, how many coils are in use, the level of calibration of how the entire system works together, the-
entries.trigger: Uh huh. What if we could shrink the area where a ship is likely to jump in? Shrink it to, say, a hundred cubic kilometers, or less?

entries.skippy_text: Ooooh, you know me, Joey, I'm all about cheating the laws of physics. However, give me a minute please, I want to get some popcorn and an ice cold brewski. That way, I can sit back on the couch and savor the moment, while you make a complete and total fool of yourself, with whatever moronic so-called idea your monkey brain has dreamed up. Ok, I'm ready, hit me with your best shot. Ha ha, this is going to be great!
entries.trigger: We get the idea, Skippy. A lot of variables, yup. We're not going to guess, we're going to game the system by cheating. Beat the house.

entries.skippy_text: Holy shit.
entries.trigger: Skippy? Hey, are you crunching numbers in there?
entries.context: Skippy didn't answer. He didn't say anything at all.

entries.skippy_text: You are such an asshole! I hate you.
entries.trigger: Yup.
entries.context: Skippy didn't answer. He didn't say anything at all.

entries.skippy_text: Yes. Damn it. Ugh, I hate my life. A monkey has a good idea. A freakin' monkey! Unbelievable! The universe is so unfair. Yes, it will work, Joe, I can control where a ship jumps to within less than a hundred kilometers. Nowhere near as accurate as I am with our own jumps, of course, there are too many variables I can't analyze without being on the enemy ship before it jumps. A hundred, even a thousand kilometers is close enough, our missiles will be able to target and hit the enemy ship, before it can detect the missiles and raise shields. Any ship jumping in will be a sitting duck. And, hey, in case you think you're soooooo freakin' smart, I'm not going to create an especially flat area of spacetime. What I'm going to do is create an area where the flatness is negative.
entries.trigger: Uh huh, got it. Is that a yes?

entries.skippy_text: No. Ask one of your scientist monkeys to explain it to you, if they can. Ha! For them, figuring out how the universe really works will be simple, compared to explaining quantum topology to you.
entries.trigger: Negative flatness? Isn't that a fancy way of saying it's curved in the other direction?

entries.skippy_text: Uh oh,
entries.trigger: The trouble started when our first missile impacted, it hit the center of the tanker, not the aft end. Skippy later admitted he should have programmed those missiles to anticipate the tankers coming through the wormhole more ponderously than the surveyor and the destroyer had. Momentum carried the a
entries.context: The trouble started when our first missile impacted, it hit the center of the tanker, not the aft end. Skippy later admitted he should have programmed those missiles to anticipate the tankers coming t When our missile dove into the open wormhole, and caused release of energy stored in the jump drive coils of the first tanker, it also alerted the second tanker that something was wrong, very wrong,

entries.skippy_text: Uh oh? What's going wrong in the world of Skippy?
entries.trigger: The trouble started when our first missile impacted, it hit the center of the tanker, not the aft end. Skippy later admitted he should have programmed those missiles to anticipate the tankers coming through the wormhole more ponderously than the surveyor and the destroyer had. Momentum carried the a
entries.context: The trouble started when our first missile impacted, it hit the center of the tanker, not the aft end. Skippy later admitted he should have programmed those missiles to anticipate the tankers coming t When our missile dove into the open wormhole, and caused release of energy stored in the jump drive coils of the first tanker, it also alerted the second tanker that something was wrong, very wrong,

entries.skippy_text: Something is wrong in the world of monkeys, Colonel Joe. We have a potential problem.
entries.trigger: The trouble started when our first missile impacted, it hit the center of the tanker, not the aft end. Skippy later admitted he should have programmed those missiles to anticipate the tankers coming through the wormhole more ponderously than the surveyor and the destroyer had. Momentum carried the a
entries.context: The trouble started when our first missile impacted, it hit the center of the tanker, not the aft end. Skippy later admitted he should have programmed those missiles to anticipate the tankers coming t When our missile dove into the open wormhole, and caused release of energy stored in the jump drive coils of the first tanker, it also alerted the second tanker that something was wrong, very wrong,

entries.skippy_text: Whether or not it is a problem, depends on your mission parameters. Before you ask more stupid monkey-brained questions, I'll lay out the issue for you; the second tanker is very likely not going to jump into the rendezvous. The first tanker exploded while it was partly in the wormhole, it hadn't fully cleared the event horizon. Backblast would have been visible on the other end of the wormhole, no way could the second tanker have missed that event.
entries.trigger: A potential problem? You're not sure if it's a problem or not?

entries.skippy_text: Course laid in, but I expect the second tanker jumped away to an alternate destination already, as soon as it saw something went wrong with its sister ship.
entries.trigger: Correct, Major, the problem here is that tanker won't be carrying our cover story of a Jeraptha task force marauding through Thuranin territory, they're going to have a much more interesting tale to tell; a ship gets hit while it is still inside a jump wormhole. When they hear that, the Thuranin command is going to want to know how an enemy could possibly know precisely where a ship will emerge fr

entries.skippy_text: I can do it, I can't do it with the accuracy we would prefer. Fortunately, the Thuranin are still under the mistaken impression that quantum effects tend toward randomness, a common misconception of lesser developed species. Because I know how the universe really works, I've been able to map the pattern of the quantum resonators, unwind their effect from the residual wormhole signature, and make a reasonably good guess as to where that second tanker ship went. By reasonable, I mean I can tell where that ship jumped to, within six hundred thousand kilometers.
entries.trigger: So, you can't do it?
entries.context: We jumped to where the first tanker had tried to jump in from, immediately engaged our stealth field, and began hammering away with an active sensor search, to determine whether there were any ships i

entries.skippy_text: Wait! There is some extra good news, Colonel Joe, by some stroke of luck, or luck as you monkeys think of it, that second tanker is the one I infected when we flew by on our space dive, so it will be dropping off drones as it jumps. That makes it much easier to follow. I'm pinging the drones now. And, yes! Got a response. I know exactly where that ship is. Hmm, that's interesting, it's going to a secondary rendezvous point, it is supposed to go to the secondary rendezvous if there is trouble at the original rendezvous location. Oh, darn it, the tanker is probably there already, and it's supposed to remain there almost six hours. After that, the tanker's orders, if no other ships appear at the secondary rendezvous, is for it to make its way back to its base star system, using a random course. Damn it, we won't be able to use our neat trick of knowing exactly where a ship will jump in.
entries.trigger: Great! Program a jump for us, and we will-

entries.skippy_text: Within ten, twelve thousand kilometers, most likely, yes.
entries.trigger: No, But we do know, from the drone, pretty much exactly where that ship is now, right?

entries.skippy_text: A weak damping field, yes, I had to disassemble much of that unit's mechanism to repair the ship. Hmmm. You are proposing we act like a real pirate ship?
entries.trigger: Good, great. This is perfect. If that ship does escape us, I don't want it to see us trying to use that trick again. Here's what we're going to do; we jump into where that ship is, and launch missiles as soon as we clear the wormhole. We can project a damping field, right, to prevent that tanker from jumping away?

entries.skippy_text: I love it! Jump course plotted and programmed in, missiles are ready for launch.
entries.trigger: Something like that, yeah.

entries.skippy_text: Oh, for crying out loud, you monkeys will take forever, The answer is yes, Joe, the forward section of that ship is still partly intact, and even I can't tell if anyone is left alive in there. Their computer core is in that section, it would be wise for us to not leave that behind.
entries.trigger: Missiles inbound!

entries.skippy_text: Got it! We're too far away for me to hack directly into the drone. Pilot, I loaded the coordinates into the nav system.
entries.trigger: We figured that, Skippy,
entries.context: Having taken care of the four ships, we now needed to clean up after the flight recorder drones they had ejected. Because three of the ships had been hit with no warning, they had not been able to lau

entries.skippy_text: Whoa! Another jump already? What are you doing, monkey?
entries.trigger: Take us there, pilot,
entries.context: Desai gave me a thumbs up and her fingers flew over the controls. In the past, Skippy would have programmed the autopilot to take us to the drone, and all Desai would have done was press a button to e

entries.skippy_text: No, no, no, no, no, no. We're not done here, dumdum. That was only one drone. Thuranin ships typically drop off drones in sets of three, in case one or two drones are destroyed by whatever threat caused the ship to eject drones.
entries.trigger: Jumping to the next set of coordinates, wherever that ship dropped off a drone.

entries.skippy_text: Duh. Each drone in a set of three has a priority, the primary drone responds first. If the primary drone doesn't respond, the secondary drone does, and so on. And after one drone responds, any other drone in the set will no longer respond to the original retrieval signal, they switch to another retrieval code.
entries.trigger: Damn it. Why didn't you tell us that? Hey, wait. You sent out the signal, and only one drone pinged us its location.

entries.skippy_text: Nope, I didn't have time to download the full set of codes. But any Thuranin ship that comes looking for the drones will have the full set of codes.
entries.trigger: Great, fine. You have that other retrieval code, right?

entries.skippy_text: Joey, as entertaining as this rant is, and I'm sure you were winding up for a full-blown award winning diatribe aimed at me, please cool your jets a minute. I didn't mention not having downloaded the other codes, because I don't need a copy of them. The Thuranin are unimaginative and predictable, I can figure out the what other codes must be, based on their pattern. And, mmm, yes, I sent my test retrieval code, and another drone just responded. We're good, pilot, the drone's location is in the nav system.
entries.trigger: Damn it! We're screwed, you little shithead. Why didn't you tell us that? Now we've got three drones out there, two of them contain their ship's real flight logs, the Thuranin will know somebody screwed with the data in that one drone. I know you are absent-minded sometimes, but this is inexcusable, Skippy. You can't do-

entries.skippy_text: Hey, it gets back for all the times you make me feel foolish. Payback is a bitch, buddy-boy. Anywho, we're good, we can find the other drones and alter their flight logs also. Mission will soon be accomplished, Joe! Too bad we don't have any fresh bananas to celebrate with.
entries.trigger: You just love yanking my chain, don't you, Skippy?

entries.skippy_text: That's it, we're done, The last drone now contains the altered version of the flight logs. I suggest we skedaddle out of here, on the tiny chance a Thuranin ship happens to already be searching for the surveyor and its escorts.
entries.trigger: You just love yanking my chain, don't you, Skippy?
entries.context: Damn, locating all those drones was tedious, it took us four full days for Skippy to be absolutely confident he had located all of them.

entries.skippy_text: What? Our mission isn't done, Joe. I know we-
entries.trigger: Right, good idea. Pilot, set course for Earth,
entries.context: Damn, locating all those drones was tedious, it took us four full days for Skippy to be absolutely confident he had located all of them.

entries.skippy_text: Whoa! You're making that decision without checking with me first? Good luck getting the jump drive to remain calibrated all the way back to Earth, without me.
entries.trigger: This SpecOps mission is over, Skippy. UNEF Command sent us on this fool's errand, with the assumption that our home planet was safe, because the wormhole was shut down. Now we know that shutting down our local wormhole has only made Earth somewhat more safe than it was, not entirely safe. UNEF, and our governments back home, need to know that. I report to them, not to you. I want the fastest cours

entries.skippy_text: Depends-
entries.trigger: Do I command this ship or not, Skippy?

entries.skippy_text: Yes,
entries.trigger: Command must be an absolute, Skippy. This is a simple yes, or no.

entries.skippy_text: You're right, you're right. I do have a lot to think about, and I need more data. Besides, you monkeys have done a good job out here, and you all deserve a big bunch of fresh bananas.
entries.trigger: Look, Skippy, I told you that we would help you find your magic radio, and we will. Think about what we've seen out here. A previously unknown Elder site that has a big mysterious hole scooped out of it. An entire civilization that is extinct because their planet was moved by Elder technology, after the Elders supposedly left this galaxy. An Elder AI that is now a dead lump of metal. Comm nodes th

entries.skippy_text: We have resonators aboard, yes. We didn't deploy them at the time, because they wouldn't have been much use, Joe. We were only capable of microjumps then, with short jumps like that, both ends of the wormhole are so close in real space, it is almost impossible to mask their connection. Also, our jump drive was so badly out of calibration, each jump was like ringing a bell that could be heard halfway across the galaxy. Trying to mask that with quantum resonators would have been like throwing stones into the ocean during a hurricane; sure, there are some extra ripples in the water, they're not going to affect the waves.
entries.trigger: Hey, Skippy, why didn't we use these super-duper quantum resonator things, when we were being chased by a whole squadron of Thuranin destroyers? We have resonators aboard, right?
entries.context: Damn it, even when he was being nice, he was an asshole.

entries.skippy_text: Duh. If I thought it would have helped, I would have launched our quantum resonators, we have almost a hundred of them. Or we had almost a hundred, I needed to use most of them to rebuild the ship. Now we have three of them left.
entries.trigger: Oh.
entries.context: Damn it, even when he was being nice, he was an asshole.

entries.skippy_text: You wanted me to fix the ship or not?
entries.trigger: Three? Only three?

entries.skippy_text: Hmmf, You have no idea how amazing. I had to build machines to create exotic matter, that your monkey brains can't even imagine. And I'm still waiting for that cake you promised me, back when you were on Newark.
entries.trigger: Sorry, Skippy, I know you did an amazing, incredible job, all by yourself.

entries.skippy_text: Great! Everyone can enjoy cake, and sit around talking about how awesome I am, even though you monkeys can't truly appreciate the full gloriously awesome extent of my awesomeness. Hey, I just composed a song you can sing in my honor. I call it 'Skippy the Magnificent'. It goes like this 'Skippy, oh, Skippy, we monkeys are so unworthy, you are so awesome'-
entries.trigger: Skippy, I'm sorry, I completely forgot your cake, with all the crap that went on after we left Newark behind. I will bake a very special cake for dinner, tonight. I'm headed to the galley right now, anyway.

entries.skippy_text: That'll work also.
entries.trigger: Skippy! How about we monkeys enjoy eating cake, while talking about how awesome it is that we've been able to resist the strong urge to toss you out an airlock?

entries.skippy_text: In case anyone has not heard, we are going home! Every one of us is coming home, we didn't lose a single person. Lest we forget, I'd like to take a moment to review what we have accomplished out here. I will be brief, I promise! First, we didn't blow up the ship. Yet. The Thuranin almost did that for us, but we survive humanity's first space battle. We landed on an alien planet, the first alien planet for most of us, and we survived there. We traveled across the surface of that planet, part of the way on foot, and defeated an enemy who initially had the advantage of air power and numbers. We destroyed a Kristang ship in orbit, without that ship even knowing humans were in the star system. And then, when we thought we were safely back aboard the Dutchman and all we had to do was look for another comm node, we discovered that our home planet was in danger. And, I am pleased, very pleased, to say, that threat to Earth has been eliminated, without this ship being put at serious risk. I call that a success, people!
entries.trigger: Captain, as the United Nations has never before had a warship, we can start our own traditions. I believe that in the future, champagne should be mandatory .
entries.context: Simms shook her head, saying no, she hadn't smuggled any alcohol aboard. That disappointed me, I'd been hoping our logistics officer had thought of that, until I realized I was being very unfair to he

entries.skippy_text: Oh, uh, damn, no, now that you ask, I can't think of anything to say, darn it. This is embarrassing. I guess, um, hey, for a barrel of monkeys, you don't smell as terrible as I expected?
entries.trigger: Skippy, would you like to say anything?
entries.context: Thunderous applause, no doubt aided by the champagne that was now making a second round, to refill people's cups.

entries.skippy_text: Oh, shut up, Darn it, I knew I should have posted that 'no monkeys' sign.
entries.trigger: We love you too, Skippy.
